text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

ADI IGNATIUS: Hi, I'm
Adi Ignatius, Editor

in Chief of Harvard
Business Review,

and it's my pleasure
to welcome you to--

welcome you to the season's
first episode of "HBR Now."

Our special guest today will
be journalist and author Walter
Isaacson.

And we'll be bringing
him in just a moment.

As many of you know, we
originally launched this show
back in April during lockdown.

We called it "HBR
Quarantined," and we

wanted to create a
platform to connect

with HBR's many readers who
suddenly found themselves
working from home.

Our goal was to bring in an
A-list of guests to talk about
the big issues of the moment--

the pandemic,
Black Lives Matter,

dislocations to the economy,
and how all of these

are affecting business
and career paths.

The response from all
of you was overwhelming.

We took a break for the
summer and now we're back.

And when I say
we, I mean as well

my co-host from last
season, Josh Macht,

who heads Product and
Innovation for HBR.

And I'm thrilled to introduce
our new co-host, Octavia
Goredema.

Octavia is a longtime
career coach and the founder
of the Twenty Ten Agency.

And she's now working
on a boo that's

a career guide for
underrepresented women.

We also have a new
sponsor for the season.

So, in fact, let's hear now
from our friends at Accenture.
[VIDEO PLAYBACK]

- Change is all around
us, shaped by technology
and human ingenuity.

We can make it work for
you and your business.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[PLAYBACK ENDS]

ADI IGNATIUS: And
one more little

visual before I bring in
our co-hosts and our guest.

We have a tradition of
unearthing odd little TikTok

videos that capture the
moment we're living through.
So, Roll It engineered a--
[VIDEO PLAYBACK]
- I'd like to return this.
- Oh, OK, was there a problem?

- A little bit too much fires,
UFOs, and police brutality.

- Did you unplug it
and plug it back in?
- I did.

And then a global pandemic
and murder hornets appeared.

- Do you want to
exchange that for 2021?
- No.
- Not a problem.
[SIRENS]
- Definitely defective.
[PLAYBACK ENDS]

ADI IGNATIUS: Right, so let me
[INAUDIBLE] Josh and Octavia.

First of all, welcome
Josh to season two.

They said it was
a pretend TV show.

Well, now it's a pretend TV
show with multiple seasons.
JOSH MACHT: [INAUDIBLE] Amazing.
And I'm no longer at my house.

This is our "HBR Now" studios
at Boston, in Brighton.

ADI IGNATIUS:
That's a big change.

And special welcome to
Octavia for joining us
as co-host this season.
Welcome, Octavia.
OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: Oh, thank you.
ADI IGNATIUS:

ADI IGNATIUS: Yeah,
so, Octavia, maybe

you can talk a little
bit about yourself

for people who are just
getting to know you.

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: Yeah,
so, I'm in Los Angeles.

And I'm a career coach, the
founder of Twenty Ten Agency.

I coach professionals
across the country.

And I'm mostly writing a
book, and a career guide
for underrepresented women.

So, really thrilled
to join you guys
and be a part of this show.

JOSH MACHT: So, Octavia,
we're happy to have you here.
And I'm curious, who--

as we are so lucky to get
you to agree to join us

on this show, who would be
your absolute dream guest,
not including Walter.

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: Yeah,
not including Walter.

Well, in addition to
Walter, my dream guest

would be Roz Brewer, the Chief
Operating Officer at Starbucks.
Her resume is just formidable.

In addition to her
role at Starbucks,
she's on the board of Amazon.

She was the President
and CEO at Sam's Club.

There'd be so much
to talk about.

JOSH MACHT: All right, we
can put out the big ask.
ADI IGNATIUS: Yeah.

So, just to get us
into the conversation.

So, picking up on
the TikTok video,
this is a year like none other.

Years from now, we will
remember where we were in 2020.

The combination of pandemic,
recession, a very consequential

US election is almost more
than any of us can bear.

The election is foremost
in my mind right now.

The one four years ago laid bare
how conventional understanding
of the electorate-- of the--

how bad conventional
understanding of the electorate

was and how inadequate our
forecasting tools were.

I think we had figured that we'd
be better equipped this time

around with better data
and better sources.
And then COVID-19 hit.

So, we really don't
know what's happening.
How many people will vote?
How will they vote?
How will the ballots be counted?

What external forces will
disrupt the campaign?

Will anyone even
trust the result?

It's interesting to me to see
political analysts with polling

data in hand that seems
to indicate clearly

what will happen
on November 3rd,

but no one dares
trust it after what

happened in 2016 and with all
the disruption since then.

Josh, what's your
take on the moment?
JOSH MACHT: I find it--

on the election
side, this is just,

it's got to be one of the most
extraordinary moments ever.

I find the backdrop of
what we're living through,
and the whole idea--

I think, everyone's so tense
with the election, and then

the winter coming, and
this notion of like really
going into the tough--

into the teeth of-- especially
in the Northeast, where we are,

this idea that it
feels like we're

heading into this
very tumultuous time.

On the other hand,
there's a lot of reasons

to think next year
we could even start

to see some progress and
reasons to be optimistic.

And so, I try not to lose
sight of that on the other side
as well.
How about you Octavia?

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: Yeah,
I agree with all of that.

And I think front of
mine really for me

is the impact on our
next generation in terms

of education and
also the educators.

I'm in awe of what
my kids' teachers

and the 3.2 million public
teachers across America doing,
day in, day out.

Right now, my kids
are in class on Zoom,

because in our school district
our schools are still closed.

And we're just having
to take it day by day

and just figure out
what comes next.

And I know as a parent, I'm not
used to not having the answers

in terms of how
this is going to be.

And so there's just some
really profound and important

questions that are happening
right now on the ground,

as well as with decision
makers in terms of what's
to come with the election.

ADI IGNATIUS: All
right, all good.

If you just tuned in,
this is "HBR Now."
it's time to bring in our guest.

Walter Isaacson has
led an amazing career
with many interesting chapters.

He spent 25 years
at Time Magazine,

and served as its top
editor from 1996 to 2001.

He then served as CEO of CNN and
as CEO of the Aspen Institute.

But he's probably best known as
the author of many bestselling

books that chronicle the lives
of some of the world's most
innovative minds--

Benjamin Franklin,
Albert Einstein,

and Steve Jobs, Leonardo
da Vinci, and more.

These days, he's also a
professor at Tulane University
in his hometown of New Orleans.
Walter, welcome to "HBR Now."
WALTER ISAACSON: Hey, thank you.
It's good to see you again, Adi.
ADI IGNATIUS: Yeah.

Yeah, it's also possible
he was formerly my boss.

WALTER ISAACSON: Nobody's
ever been your boss.

ADI IGNATIUS: I'd love to
start with the US election.

We're two weeks away
from what really

seems like the most
consequential election
in memory.
But I want to ask, is it?

As a chronicler of history,
and of great individuals,

and as someone who sat atop
Time Magazine for years as it

tried to take the pulse of
the nation, what's your take?

Is this more
consequential than others,

or do we just say
that every four years?

WALTER ISAACSON: No, this is
more consequential than others.

This is a major
divide in our society.

And not since 1968 have we
had such polarizing forces
in our society.

And in this case,
we have a president

who is actually putting fuel to
the flame of the divisiveness
and polarization.

So, I think it's an election
about whether the country is

going to be able to
get unified again

or whether we keep this
path of divisiveness.

Whatever you may think of the
ideologies of either party,

this one has deep consequences,
and an administration

that is really torn down some
of the norms and structures
we have in our society.

ADI IGNATIUS: For those
who are just joining us,
this is "HBR Quarantined."

If you have questions
for Walter Isaacson,

please put them in
the comments box.

And we'll try to get
to as many as we can.

Walter, if you think back, are
there any parallels in history,

though, where things seemed
to be really out of whack,

and yet, they came
back to a norm,

that the center reemerged,
the center held?

WALTER ISAACSON: Yeah, I
think America is that way.

I can quote Albert Einstein,
one of my biography subjects.

When he comes to America, he
finds after the World War II,

the rise of Joe
McCarthyism, and that sort

of very bitter attacks
on people like Jay Robert

Oppenheimer, who worked with
Einstein on the atomic bomb

project, questioning
their loyalty.

And Einstein writes to
his son, Hans Albert--
I've seen this before.
I've seen this movie before.

I've seen it where
the Nazis took over,

and then when the
Communists took over.

And then two years, three
years later, after Eisenhower

gets elected, a great president
who calmed the nation down,

Eisenhower and the mainstream
press, like Edward R Murrow,

and the Army hearings
bring Joe McCarthy down.

And Einstein says, it's
amazing, America's democracy,

it seems to have
an inner gyroscope.

Because when you think
it's going to tip over,
it knows how to right itself.

ADI IGNATIUS: Do
you have any reason

to doubt that America
still has that gyroscope?

WALTER ISAACSON: I think we
still have the gyroscope.

We're going to see a
lot in this election.

Because part of the gyroscope
is the institutional norms

and the checks and balances, and
those have been under assault.

And this is not just
an American thing.

There's been a populist, and
authoritarian populist backlash

around the world that I think
people like us-- and by people

like us, I mean people who
read the Harvard Business

Review-- should make
some pains to understand.

Because a lot of the
conventional wisdom that we

supported ended up being wrong,
where people were left behind
by globalization.

People were messed up by
everything from free trade,
to technology, to immigration.

That backlash, and that
tribalism, and nationalism,

you can see it from
Turkey to Hungary,

even to the Brexit election,
and certainly to Trump.

So, I think it's not just a US
question of whether we bounce

back, but whether the idea
of market-based liberal

constitutional
democracies can survive.
ADI IGNATIUS: So let's turn--

I have a feeling my
co-hosts are going

to want to talk to you more
later about the election.

But I want to talk
about innovation,

because that's really at the
heart of a lot of the books
that you've written.

And the list of people you've
written about are varied--

Einstein, Steve Jobs, Benjamin
Franklin, da Vinci, Kissinger.
They're all very different.

But I'm sure you've
thought about what maybe

are common characteristics
that elevate

talented, hardworking people to
this higher level of really--
of game-changing achievement.

Can you talk about
some of those?

WALTER ISAACSON: When
I started to discuss

with Steve Jobs
writing his book,
I said, why do you want me?

And he said, because
everybody you've written about

has stood at the intersection
of the arts and the sciences.

They're interested
in everything,

from the humanities
to engineering.

And by seeing things
across nature, he said,

all of nature's wonders, you
can see the patterns of nature.

And so, it did occur to
me, because you remember--

I'm sure you've been
or seen some of them--

whenever Steve Jobs
launched a product,

he'd end with that
slide on the screen

of the intersection between the
liberal arts and technology.

And he said, if you stand
at that intersection
that a creativity happened.

And I realized that was true
of Benjamin Franklin, who

was everything from a writer,
and an artist, and a musician,
to a scientist.

And we sometimes think of
him as a doddering dude,
flying a kite in the rain.

But those electricity
experiments

were the most important
scientific experiments
of the time.

Same with Einstein, when he's
stumped on general relativity,

he pulls out his violin
and plays Mozart.

And the culmination of that
is Leonardo da Vinci, who

is both a great artist, but also
an anatomist, and a zoologist,

and loves to know, as
Benjamin Franklin, Steve

Jobs, and Einstein
did, everything

he could possibly know about
every subject knowable.

ADI IGNATIUS: So, I'm going
to tout an HBR product.

We're publishing
a book next month

called Invent and
Wander, which is

the collected writings of
Jeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon.

Walter has written a
really fine introduction,

original introduction
to that book.

Can you talk a little
bit about Bezos?

He seems to be the
most successful person

of our generation, a
really interesting mind.
What's your take on Jeff Bezos?

WALTER ISAACSON: Well, as
I say in the introduction

to this wonderful book, Invent
and Wander, which is out

next month from HBR Press, he
has these same characteristics

of ever since he was a little
kid, growing up in Miami,

but also his grandfather's
ranch in Texas,
he was curious about everything.

He loved, of course, space
travel, but he loved business.
He loved nature.

And he loved books, and
writing, and philosophy.

And so, somebody who not only
had a passion and a curiosity

for everything, but that
enthusiasm that's captured

in his almost manic laugh,
when I looked at the way

he grew up, when I talked
to him about his childhood

and all the way through, you
don't create the everything

store unless you're
interested in everything.

And you're not able
to tie business,

and arts, and the humanities,
and literature to commerce,

to technology, to
engineering unless you have
that enthusiasm for everything.

So, I tried to capture
that in the introduction
to invent and Wander.

ADI IGNATIUS: It sounds
like a great book.

I think everyone should go out
and preorder a copy on Amazon
right now.

WALTER ISAACSON: I hope
Amazon gives you a discount.

ADI IGNATIUS: They
don't give discounts.

So, the last thing I want
to talk to you about,
and then we'll--

I want to bring in Octavia and
Josh, and that's leadership.

Some of the people
you've studied

are effective business
and political leaders.

We're in a moment now
that seems to call

for extraordinary leadership,
people who can guide us,

who can comfort us, who can
feel the way forward, and also
feel our pain.

Talk about what does it take
to be a great leader today?

And has that hasn't changed
in the past decades?

WALTER ISAACSON:
Well, I don't think

there's any one formula
for great leadership.

And I wrote about it for
the Harvard Business Review

once, when I did "The Ten
Lessons from Steve Jobs,"

a story that you and I worked
on and ran in your magazine.

Which is you need certain
leaders like Steve Jobs, who

are abrasive, and
aggressive, and they're just

going to have a reality
distortion field, and barrel
through things.

But every now and then,
you need a great leader

like a Tim Cook, who knows
how to consolidate things, get

things done, and build great
teams, as Steve Jobs also did.

So, I think that when I wrote
about Benjamin Franklin,

that's the greatest
team ever, which
is the founders of this nation.

But you had to have passionate
people, like John and Sam
Adams.

You had to have a person
of great rectitude,

like George Washington, and
brilliant people like Jefferson

and Madison and
also people who were

the glue that would bring them
gather, like Benjamin Franklin.

So, Jeff Bezos has a
particular style of leadership.

I think each of
us when we lead--

when I had to lead CNN, or
Time Magazine, or Aspen,

I figured out, what do I
like to do as a leader,

and then how do I
create a team around me
to become a great leader.

But the traits we
need now, to get back

to the point of your
question, is sometimes

you need certain type of
traits for a particular time.

Just as you needed a
Steve Jobs at the birth

of the personal
computer revolution.

And you listed the traits
that I feel we need now,

is empathy, honor, this notion
that you want to bring people

together, that there's
some unity, that we're
one nation with one mission.

And that especially comes from
a trait that some leaders have
and others don't.

It was not Steve
Jobs' greatest trait,

which is deep empathy for
the feelings of other people.

ADI IGNATIUS: All
right, so let me

let me bring in
Octavia and Josh to ask
more questions of Walter.

And I'll be peppering in
questions from our audience
as well.

Again, if you want to
pose a question to Walter,
type it in the comments box.
Again, this is "HBR Now."
And over to my co-hosts.

JOSH MACHT: So,
Walter, I'm curious

because you're clearly
right about people

with that intersection as you
talk about art and science.

And I don't necessarily think
of Donald Trump that way.

But yet, he is this figure
who consumes our thoughts
and our tweets all the time.

Are you compelled at
all to think about him

as someone you might want
to do a biography on?

And I'm curious how you look
at his traits in contrast

or comparison to
some of the people
that you've talked about.

WALTER ISAACSON: No,
I have no interest.

And I'm sure there are
other people who will write
biographies on Donald Trump.

It's not something
that interests me.

And think that Donald
Trump was able to tap

into a deep sense of resentment,
some anger, and some sense

that people had been frustrated
by an elite, an establishment

that had left them behind,
that looked down upon them.

And that was something that
I think a lot of people,

especially in the media and on
the coast, didn't quite feel.
I'm down in Louisiana.

And when I drive
around, especially

in middle of America,
I understand a sense
of frustration and resentment.

I think that was Donald
Trump's ability, which

is to tap into anger and
to stoke resentments.

But that's not a leadership
trait that I either admire

or that I would ever
want to write about.

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: So,
Walter, earlier this month,

Jennifer Doudna and
Emmanuelle Charpentier

were announced as the
winners at the 2020 Nobel
Prize in chemistry.

And Dr Doudna is the subject
of your next book, The Code
Breaker.

What drove your desire
to tell her story?

WALTER ISAACSON: Well, I think
the Nobel Prize Committee

put it best when they said that
this is about the code of life.

This is a type of science
that will change epochs.

When I wrote about
Einstein, it was

because the first half
of the 20th century

was a century of physics that
came out of Einstein's papers.

Whether it was relativity or
quantum theory, what you end up

with is everything
from atom bombs,

to semiconducting materials,
to GPS, to space travel,
that sort of thing.

Then, the second half of
the 20th century I think

was a century in
which innovation was
driven by digital technology.

And it comes with
three great inventions

in the early 1950s, which is
the computer, the transistor,

or microchip, and
then the network.

And when those three combined,
you get a digital revolution.

I think the first half
of the 20th century

will be a biotech
revolution based

on what happened
in 2000, which was

the sequencing of
the human genome.

But also based on what Dr Doudna
and Dr Charpentier discovered.

Which is easy to use tools,
where we can not only

read the DNA of our
species and any other,

but we can edit the
DNA of our species.

This became a lot more
relevant when coronavirus hit.

Because coronavirus is
simply a viral infection.

And CRISPR, which is
the gene editing tool

that Jennifer Doudna and
others helped develop,

is simply a way that
bacteria fight off viruses.

Bacteria do it by
remembering some
of the genetic code of viruses.

And when the viruses
attack again,
they chop up that genetic code.

In other words, it's
an immune system

that adapts to each
new wave of virus.

Which is just what
we need in this era

where we've been hit by wave
after wave of pandemics,

as if we lived in
the Middle Ages.

And so, what I
think we're seeing

that COVID, and coronavirus,
and all the viral pandemics,

and CRISPR are
going to accelerate

is a transition to the
third great innovation

revolution of our time, which
will be the biotech revolution.

I was very lucky to get on it
with Jennifer Doudna, who's
both a wonderful person.

But to catch it right when she
and Emmanuelle Charpentier,

who's the co-star of
the book, won the Nobel
Prize was pretty exciting.
I set my alarm clock.

I knew the chemistry
prize was coming out.
And I thought, it's too early.
I usually wait 40 or 50 years.

But I set my alarm
for about 4:30 AM,

because I just wanted to be
watching when the Royal Swedish

Academy did the
announcement just in case.

As soon as it happened, I
called Emmanuelle Charpentier
and Jennifer.

So, it's a good last
chapter in the book.
JOSH MACHT: That's pretty cool.
Just switching over to--

back to technological
innovation for a minute,

and especially on the
social media front,

where we see so much
innovation with people
like Zuckerberg and others.

And I'm curious if you
could talk a little bit

about balancing the
need for that innovation

against the negative
effects of people

not always understanding
how social media shapes
public opinion.

WALTER ISAACSON: Well, I think
the biggest thing that happened
in that field happened today.

It probably got buried by
tweets of the President.

But the Justice Department, and
many states attorney general

have filed an antitrust
suit against Google.

I think what happened is you
have four great companies--

Facebook, Amazon,
Apple, and Google.

And especially in the case
of Google and Facebook,

and to some extent Amazon,
there's certain antitrust--
well, definitely Amazon--
antitrust issues.

When it comes to Facebook,
it's particularly important.

Because Facebook is not only the
dominant social media platform,

but once it was allowed to buy
WhatsApp and buy Instagram,

it almost just became
a monopoly in some ways

for a certain aspect
of social media.

And why that's important is
because the business model

of Amazon, which is based
only really on advertising,

has a incentive to enrage
people, to engage them,

to bring them down
rabbit holes, to get them

more and more excited about
their particular ideological
passions.

And so, instead of doing what
Zuckerberg and others thought

they were doing at the
beginning of Facebook, which

is to connect us, it's
ended up dividing us.

And I thought social
media was great.
I'm on Twitter.

I sometimes use
Facebook and Instagram.

But I think about three
or four years ago,

I began to get the sense
that social media was

doing more harm than
good to our democracy.
I definitely feel that now.

And it would be
great, in my mind,

if we had lots of
competing companies.

Because I think
a Facebook that's

protected by Section 230 that
gives it a lot of immunity

for whatever people
post on its platform,

and then people post and
repost things that are hateful,

and then Facebook's
own algorithm

not only publishes
that, but amplifies

that, I think hopefully in
the next couple of years

we're going to get a Congress
that in a bipartisan way

can say, how do we
take on the insidious
effects of social media.

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: So,
Walter, in addition

to being a best-selling
biographer,

you're a professor
of history at Tulane.

As a result of this
pandemic, parents, educators,
students are pivoting fast.

What are your thoughts
on the challenges

we face with the closure and
tentative reopening of schools
and campuses?

WALTER ISAACSON: I'm
very much in favor

of schools, K
through 12 schools,

and also college campuses
trying to reopen.

Down here in New Orleans,
I've supported the mayor

very strongly, who
for months said

we're going to shut
down bars, we're

going to shut down
casinos, we're

going to shut every
live music venue,

because we're going to keep
in mind that our number one

priority is making sure kids
at least have some opportunity
to get back to school.

Because this divide
in our society, which

has gotten worse over
the past 20 years,

is exacerbated by differences
in education opportunities,

and those differences
have been heightened,

especially when people were
trying to do distance learning.

I think most of what you learn
in school, and even in college,

involves teamwork,
collaboration, socializing,

the social skills you get,
being able to work together.

So, I think as a country
we should have focused

on doing everything possible,
including at Tulane,

students are tested
twice a week.

There are special dorms
for people who have COVID.

But figuring out everything
we could possibly

do to have in-person
instruction when we could

and shutting down
things that, in my mind,

aren't fully necessary, such
as the bars of Bourbon Street.

ADI IGNATIUS: So, we have
a lot of people watching,

and we have a lot of
questions coming in.

Again, if you're just joining
us, this is "HBR Now."

If you have questions
for Walter Isaacson,
type them into the comments box.
So, let's do a few of these.

So, this is from Clay
from Tulsa, Oklahoma.

He's asking, and you've started
to answer this with your-- what

you were saying about social
media, but there's more to say.

The question is, with so
much misinformation today,

people are left not
really knowing what
or whom to believe.
How do we turn this around?

WALTER ISAACSON: Adi and I grew
up in the great Time, Inc.,

in the 1980s and 1990s,
when we were pretty much

trained not to try
to be ideological,

and to report things,
and to check them.

And it with magazines,
like Time, and Newsweek,

and US News, and networks,
and even publications,

both on the left and the
right, from the New Republic

to the National Review,
that set a certain standard,

so that we could have
a diversity of opinion,

but we shared a
common set of facts.
